Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Insect mouthparts as indicators of excessive fine sediment in streams
Award.AbstractNarration:
Excessive fine-sediment in streams is the leading cause of surface water degradation in the United States and across the world. Fine-sediment transport and deposition on the stream bottom is a natural process; however, human activities can result in excessive amounts of sediment delivery to streams where it harms reproductive habitat for fish and other stream biota. Fine sediment is hard to measure directly in the stream thus this research seeks to develop insect-based indicators as proxies for monitoring fine-sediment conditions on the stream bottom. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Beixin Wang at Nanjing Agricultural University. Using the agricultural streams of southeast China as study sites will allow extension of the sediment gradient used in statistical models. For environmental managers in the United States and across the world, the findings of this research are of potential value in assisting with the identification of biologically-relevant changes in stream fine sediment conditions and support efforts to balance economic needs while protecting critical stream habitat.

By using the mouthpart characteristics of stream insect grazers, this research represents a novel approach to the development of sediment indicators. This method will not only identify trait-based indicators, but may also reveal causal mechanisms associated with macroinvertebrate sensitivity to inorganic fine sediment. Stream insects will be collected across a wide gradient of fine sediment conditions and examined using a Scanning Electron Microscope. Mouthpart structure and wear will be quantified and used to categorize insect tolerance. The hypothesis of this research is to show that the structure of insect mouthparts and corresponding wear on their mandibles are a useful biologic indicator of excessive inorganic fine sediment conditions on the bottom of streams. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I conducted two different research projects during my 2015 EAPSI Fellowship. The first project was to examine the effect of excessive fine sediment in streams on invertebrate mouthparts.  Working with graduate students and faculty at the Entomology lab at Nanjing Agricultural University, we developed techniques for dissecting and mounting mouthpart for observing mandible wear under a Scanning Electron Microscope. The results of this work will hopefully lead to a better understating of the mechanistic causes of stream invertebrate sensitivity to sediment conditions and allow improve the ability to use stream insects as indicators of sediment pollution. Currently, I'm using these techniques to examine insects in streams of the Pacific Northwest and working towards developing a new criteria for identify sediment sensitive taxa.

The second project was to determine if  algal and macroinvertebrates can be used as indicators of nutrient over-enrichment in the Karstic Lakes of Jiuzhaigou National Park and World Heritage Site. Jiuzhaigou Valley, located in Southeast China is home to  some of the most scenic and pristine Karstic lakes in the world. However, increasing tourism  pressure at this World Heritage site is beginning to degrade lake habitat through nutrient enrichment. If this degradation continues, the lakes will become over-enriched and will lose their clarity - a situation that is nearly impossible to reverse. For two weeks in July, I worked with a team of researchers from Shanghai Normal University and Jiuzhaigou National Park to determine if lake biota could be used as an early-warning system for nutrient enrichment in the lakes. To this end we collected insects, algae and macrophyte from lakes and streams in the park and developed a technique for mapping benthic macrophyte cover. The results of this work will hopefully lead to a better understating of the how to manage other tourist destinations with Karstic lakes around the world. Currently, we are analyzing results and working on a paper to be submitted to a peer review journal.
